body: great idea @juanitorduz. I think that is what is usually called "expanding window" ? Mixing this up with the `SlidingWindowSplitter` class might be a bit confusing in naming? I would propose to either rename this class to just `WindowSplitter` then with an argument `mode: ["sliding", "expanding"]` or a new class `ExpandingWindowSplitter`?

> great idea @juanitorduz. I think that is what is usually called "expanding window" ? Mixing this up with the `SlidingWindowSplitter` class might be a bit confusing in naming? I would propose to either rename this class to just `WindowSplitter` then with an argument `mode: ["sliding", "expanding"]` or a new class `ExpandingWindowSplitter`?

Yes, this naming makes sense üëç

Thanks for the suggestion @juanitorduz! This is related to #520. 

This may be obvious, but I'm always a little confused by the window splitters. Since our forecasters remember the training data they see, all of them are technically working with an expanding window, no? When would you use an `ExpandingWindowSplitter`?

Ups! Sorry for the duplicated issue, I was filtering by the keyword `SlidingWindowSplitter`. 

In addition to @aiwalter 's input in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/520 (thanks for that!) I have some additional comment: In many practical situations I need the expanded-folds themselves. For example, when doing back testing: Suppose I need to run a forecast model on a daily basis (we train and predict on a daily basis) and I want to study the performance of an already selected model (let us say ARIMA(p=1, i=0, q=1), i.e. I do not need to select any parameters). Then I would like to train and predict on the expanded-folds to do an error analysis and understand what to expect of the model when deployed to production. 
Does it make sense? üò¨ Is there a way of doing this with sktime 0.5.0?

Scikit-Learn has already something similar: [TimeSeriesSplit](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.model_selection.TimeSeriesSplit.html#sklearn.model_selection.TimeSeriesSplit), but id does not offer as many options as `SlidingWindowSplitter`.

@juanitorduz, one additional point perhaps on your comment: we should be careful and not mix evaluation and tuning. Tuning are wrappers/compositors like `GridSearchCV` in `sklearn`; evaluation should be external to any estimator. We are still working on the evaluation/monitoring module - let us know if you are interested to contribute.

issue.title: Adding forecasting backtest/evaluate function

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I would like to add a backtesting class. We should ideally then also implement an expanding window splitter functionality as discussed in #552 . But the `Backtest` would just receive a splitter as an argument.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A class like `Backtest` (naming to be discussed) with a signature like this:
```python
class Backtest(object):
    """Backtest forecasters

    Parameters
    ----------
    forecaster: estimator object
    splitter: splitter object
        e.g. SlidingWindowSplitter
    score: function
        A function like smape_loss that has y_pred, y_test as arguments and returns a float

    Returns
    ----------
    error: float
        Average error of fitted estimators calculated by means of the score function
    """
```

The class should have a `fit()` function like a regular estimator object. I guess a `predict()` function does not make sense here. The class will be able to also take a `forecaster` of type `ForecastingGridSearchCV`, as in production people might refit and tune the model by progress in time.

Optionally, the class can print the number of fits, like in `ForecastingGridSearchCV` when fitting.

I am not sure on how to structure the return and what else should be returned, I guess just return `self` and have the rest as class variables? We could do sth like in `ForecastingGridSearchCV` with the `cv_results_` variable, so we could also store there the errors, predictions  and also the params of each iteration (because params might differ when using a grid search as forecaster).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29627036/104709492-4ea57100-571f-11eb-9311-bf3920db1bcf.png)

Where should a class `Backtest` be placed in the `sktime` class structure? I propose `sktime/sktime/forecasting/model_backtest/_backtest.py`.
